lessons.title: From a Local DB to an Online SQL Database

content.body_md:
Preface

From a Local DB to an Online SQL Database

Why deployed apps need a cloud database that‚Äôs available 24/7

You‚Äôve already created a database locally on your own computer. That‚Äôs perfect for learning, prototyping, and quick experiments. But the moment you deploy an app for teammates or customers, your data must be reachable anytime, from anywhere. That‚Äôs where an online SQL database comes in: a managed, network‚Äëaccessible relational database with security, backups, and scaling built in.

What is an SQL database?

An SQL database stores information in tables (rows and columns) and enforces relationships through keys and constraints. You use SQL (Structured Query Language) to read and modify data‚ÄîJOIN tables, filter with WHERE, aggregate with GROUP BY, and keep integrity with PRIMARY/FOREIGN keys and CHECK/UNIQUE constraints.

Local vs. Online ‚Äî what changes?

Local (on your PC)

  • Zero setup, fast iteration, no internet required.
  • Great for one‚Äëperson development and testing.
  • Limits: data lives on one machine; hard to share; manual backups; no true multi‚Äëuser concurrency across devices.

Online (cloud/hosted)

  • Accessible to your app and users from anywhere, 24/7.
  • Multi‚Äëuser concurrency, roles/permissions, automated backups, high availability.
  • Considerations: network/SSL, secret management, cost, and latency (choose a close region).

Why your deployed app needs an online DB

  • Always on: the database isn‚Äôt tied to your laptop being open.
  • Shared state: all users see the same up‚Äëto‚Äëdate data.
  • Reliability: backups, point‚Äëin‚Äëtime recovery, and failover options.
  • Security: encrypted connections (SSL), passwords/roles, auditability.
  • Scale: handle traffic spikes with pooling and right‚Äësized compute.

What changes in your app code?

  • Connection string in secrets: store credentials in environment variables or a secrets file, not in code (e.g., postgresql://user:pass@host/db?sslmode=require).
  • Use SSL and pooling: production databases require SSL; web apps benefit from connection pooling.
  • Migrations: apply schema changes via SQL scripts or a tool (e.g., Alembic). Prefer idempotent DDL (IF NOT EXISTS).
  • Environments: separate dev / staging / prod databases or branches to test safely.
  • Resilience: add timeouts/retries for transient errors; keep writes transactional and idempotent where possible.
  • Monitoring: log slow queries, watch error rates, and set health checks.

When to stay local vs go online

  • Stay local for solo prototypes, classroom exercises, or offline demos.
  • Go online before sharing with others, embedding in a public site, or relying on data that must be durable and always available.

Up next: we‚Äôll provision a serverless Postgres database online (e.g., Neon), create at least one table, and connect your Streamlit app to it‚Äîso your data is live, durable, and accessible around the clock.

Video Tutorial: Neon Setup Walkthrough

Neon Setup

Set up Neon: account, project, table, and connection string

We'll create a Neon project, build a table in the SQL Editor, and copy the pooled connection string

Neon is a serverless PostgreSQL platform that provides fast startup, autoscaling, and a pooled connection endpoint ideal for web apps. This page walks you through the initial setup.

  • Official site: https://neon.tech
  • Documentation: https://neon.tech/docs
  • Console (sign up / sign in): https://console.neon.tech

How to sign up: open the Neon Console and create an account (email or common OAuth providers). After verifying your account, you'll land in the dashboard where you can create your first project.

Step 1

Create a Neon project

Choose name, PostgreSQL version 17, cloud provider, and closest region

  1. In the Neon console, click Create project.
  2. Set the following:
    • Project name: any name (e.g., attendance-demo)
    • PostgreSQL version: 17
    • Cloud: AWS
    • Region: select the closest to your users
  3. Click Create to finish.
Step 2

Create a table in Neon (SQL Editor)

Run DDL and seed rows so your app has data to show

Open SQL Editor ‚Üí select your branch & database ‚Üí paste and Run the following:

-- Optional: app schema
CREATE SCHEMA IF NOT EXISTS app;

-- Employees table
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS app.employees (
  employee_id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
  first_name  TEXT NOT NULL,
  last_name   TEXT NOT NULL,
  email       TEXT UNIQUE,
  department  TEXT,
  job_title   TEXT,
  hire_date   DATE NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_DATE,
  status      TEXT NOT NULL CHECK (status IN ('active','inactive')),
  created_at  TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
);

-- Seed rows (safe to re-run)
INSERT INTO app.employees (employee_id, first_name, last_name, email, department, job_title, status)
VALUES
  ('E1001','Mary','Kareem','[email protected]','Sales','Rep','active'),
  ('E1002','John','Ali','[email protected]','Ops','Assistant','active')
ON CONFLICT (employee_id) DO NOTHING;
Step 3

Get your pooled connection string

Use Overview ‚Üí Connect and copy the URL with -pooler in the hostname

  1. From your project, go to Overview ‚Üí Connect.
  2. Toggle Connection pooling ON (if not already), then copy the pooled connection string (hostname contains -pooler).
  3. Keep all query parameters (e.g., sslmode=require); Neon enforces SSL.

Why the pooled URL? Web UIs like Streamlit open many short‚Äëlived connections. The pooled endpoint (PgBouncer) absorbs this load and keeps your app responsive.

Next: proceed to the Streamlit page to add secrets, install dependencies, and build a simple app that reads and writes to app.employees.

lessons.title: Neon + Streamlit: Secrets, App, Run & Deploy

content.body_md:
Streamlit Setup

Build & Run Your Streamlit App (in GitHub Codespaces)

Connect to Neon (serverless Postgres), show data, and insert rows

This page is self‚Äëcontained and starts from Step 1. You'll run Streamlit from a GitHub Codespace, connect to your Neon Postgres using a pooled connection string, and render a working UI.

Step 1

Open Your GitHub Codespace

We run Streamlit inside Codespaces so it can forward a web port

  1. Go to your GitHub repo ‚Üí click Code ‚Üí Codespaces ‚Üí Create codespace (or open an existing one).
  2. In the Codespace VS Code window, confirm you see your project files in the Explorer.
  3. Ports will be auto‚Äëforwarded when you run Streamlit; you'll open the forwarded URL in a browser.

Tip: The workspace path typically looks like /workspaces/.

Step 2

Add Secrets (Neon Pooled Connection)

Create .streamlit/secrets.toml with your pooled URL

  1. In the Codespace, create a folder .streamlit at the project root.
  2. Create a file .streamlit/secrets.toml and paste your Neon pooled SQLAlchemy URL (host contains -pooler):
# .streamlit/secrets.toml
[connections.neon]
# Use your NEON pooled endpoint; keep sslmode=require
url = "postgresql+psycopg2://USER:PASSWORD@ep-xxxx-pooler.REGION.neon.tech/DB?sslmode=require"

Why pooled? PgBouncer handles many short‚Äëlived web connections efficiently.

Step 3

Install Dependencies

Minimal requirements for Streamlit + Postgres

  1. Create requirements.txt with:
streamlit
sqlalchemy
psycopg2-binary
  1. Install them:
pip install -r requirements.txt
Step 4

Create the Streamlit App

Copy/paste into streamlit_app.py

import streamlit as st
from sqlalchemy import text

st.set_page_config(page_title="Neon + Streamlit", page_icon="üü¢", layout="centered")
st.title("Neon + Streamlit (Postgres)")
st.caption("Serverless Postgres on Neon, UI with Streamlit")

# 1) Connect via secrets (.streamlit/secrets.toml)
conn = st.connection("neon", type="sql")

# 2) Optional bootstrap ‚Äî create schema/table if missing
#    Safe to run behind a pooled connection for simple IF NOT EXISTS DDL
with conn.session as s:
    s.execute(text("CREATE SCHEMA IF NOT EXISTS app"))
    s.execute(text("""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS app.employees (
            employee_id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
            first_name  TEXT NOT NULL,
            last_name   TEXT NOT NULL,
            email       TEXT UNIQUE,
            department  TEXT,
            job_title   TEXT,
            hire_date   DATE NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_DATE,
            status      TEXT NOT NULL CHECK (status IN ('active','inactive')),
            created_at  TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
        )
    """))
    s.commit()

# 3) Insert form
with st.form("add_employee"):
    st.subheader("Add employee")
    eid   = st.text_input("Employee ID", placeholder="E1003")
    first = st.text_input("First name")
    last  = st.text_input("Last name")
    email = st.text_input("Email (optional)")
    dept  = st.text_input("Department (optional)")
    title = st.text_input("Job title (optional)")
    status = st.selectbox("Status", ["active", "inactive"], index=0)
    if st.form_submit_button("Insert row"):
        if not (eid and first and last):
            st.error("Employee ID, first name, and last name are required.")
        else:
            try:
                with conn.session as s:
                    s.execute(
                        text("""INSERT INTO app.employees
                                (employee_id, first_name, last_name, email, department, job_title, status)
                                VALUES (:eid, :fn, :ln, :em, :dp, :jt, :st)"""),
                        dict(eid=eid, fn=first, ln=last, em=email or None,
                             dp=dept or None, jt=title or None, st=status)
                    )
                    s.commit()
                st.success(f"Inserted employee {eid}")
            except Exception as e:
                st.error(f"Insert failed: {e}")

# 4) Table view (cached)
st.subheader("Employees")
df = conn.query(
    "SELECT employee_id, first_name, last_name, email, department, job_title, status, created_at "
    "FROM app.employees ORDER BY created_at DESC",
    ttl="5m"
)
st.dataframe(df, use_container_width=True)

# 5) Health check
st.caption("DB time (server):")
st.write(conn.query("SELECT now() AS server_time").iloc[0]["server_time"])

The app connects via st.connection("neon", type="sql"), bootstraps the table if missing, lets you insert a row, and shows the dataset.

Step 5

Run Streamlit in Codespaces

Forward a port and open in your browser

  1. From the Codespace terminal, run:
streamlit run streamlit_app.py --server.address 0.0.0.0 --server.port 8000
  1. Open the Ports panel in Codespaces (bottom or left), find port 8000, and click the globe icon to open it in your browser.

If prompted, set the port to Public to share the link; otherwise keep it private.

Result

What You Should See

Form to add an employee + live table view

Use the form to add a new employee, then confirm the row appears at the top of the table. The server time confirms your database connection is live.

Help

Troubleshooting & Tips

Most issues are secrets, pooling, or ports

  • "secrets not found": Ensure the file is .streamlit/secrets.toml (correct path) and the key is [connections.neon] with a valid url.
  • "connection refused/SSL": Use the pooled Neon URL (host has -pooler) and include sslmode=require.
  • Port not opening: Use the exact command above with --server.address 0.0.0.0 and check the Ports panel to open 8000.
¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

Add-On

Extend Your App: Attendance Log (Neon + Streamlit)

Assumes app.employees already exists ‚Äî we‚Äôll only add and use app.attendance_log

Got it. Here‚Äôs the clean add-on that keeps your existing employees table untouched. You‚Äôll:

  • Create a new table app.attendance_log in Neon (with FK ‚Üí app.employees).
  • Update your Streamlit app to read/write attendance (check-in/out, status/notes) without re-defining employees.
Step 1

Create the new table in Neon (no employees duplication)

Run in Neon ‚Üí SQL Editor (or via psql)

Use Neon ‚Üí SQL Editor and run only this DDL/DML:

-- New table: attendance_log (references existing app.employees)
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS app.attendance_log (
  log_id         BIGSERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
  employee_id    TEXT NOT NULL REFERENCES app.employees(employee_id)
                   ON UPDATE CASCADE ON DELETE RESTRICT,
  date           DATE NOT NULL,
  check_in_time  TIMESTAMPTZ,
  check_out_time TIMESTAMPTZ,
  status         TEXT,   -- e.g., 'Present','Sick','Leave'
  notes          TEXT,
  CONSTRAINT attendance_unique_per_day UNIQUE (employee_id, date)
);

-- Helpful index for common filters
CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_attendance_employee_date
  ON app.attendance_log (employee_id, date);

-- Optional: seed attendance for *today* for all current employees (safe to re-run)
INSERT INTO app.attendance_log (employee_id, date, check_in_time, status)
SELECT employee_id, CURRENT_DATE, now(), 'Present'
FROM app.employees
ON CONFLICT (employee_id, date) DO NOTHING;
Step 2

Update your Streamlit app to use the new table

No secrets change ‚Ä¢ No employees DDL repetition ‚Ä¢ Attendance only

  • No changes to your .streamlit/secrets.toml.
  • The code below ensures app.attendance_log exists and uses it; it does not recreate app.employees.

Replace / extend your streamlit_app.py with the section below (or add it as a new page if you‚Äôre using multipage apps):

... (content unchanged for brevity) ...
Step 3

Pattern you‚Äôll reuse for more tables

Scale your schema safely, one feature at a time

  1. DDL in Neon: CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS app.(‚Ä¶) with FKs to core keys (e.g., employee_id) and indexes for your filters.
  2. Optional app bootstrap: repeat only the new table‚Äôs CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS in your app so fresh environments don‚Äôt break.
  3. Read/Write in Streamlit: conn.query("SELECT ‚Ä¶") for reads; transactional writes via with conn.session as s: s.execute(text(...), params); s.commit().

This keeps your schema growing without touching the parts that already work.

¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

lessons.title: Deploying Streamlit ‚Ä¢ Make It a Public App

content.body_md:
Deploy

Deploying Streamlit & Making It Public

Codespaces ‚Üí GitHub ‚Üí Streamlit Community Cloud

This guide takes your working Streamlit app and puts it online as a public app. You‚Äôll keep secrets out of Git, push to GitHub, and deploy on Streamlit Community Cloud ‚Äî then add the same secrets in the cloud UI.

0)

Preflight (in your Codespace)

Keep secrets out of Git!

Make sure you have a local secrets file and it‚Äôs ignored:

mkdir -p .streamlit
printf "[connections.neon]\nurl = \"postgresql+psycopg2://USER:PASSWORD@ep-xxxx-pooler.REGION.neon.tech/DB?sslmode=require\"\n" > .streamlit/secrets.toml
echo ".streamlit/secrets.toml" >> .gitignore

You‚Äôll paste the same block into Streamlit Cloud‚Äôs Secrets UI later. Streamlit recommends using secrets.toml and never committing secrets.

requirements.txt (example)

streamlit
sqlalchemy
psycopg2-binary

If you already have a requirements.txt, just ensure these are listed.

Repo layout (example)

learningexamples/
‚îú‚îÄ app.py                 # your Streamlit entry point
‚îú‚îÄ requirements.txt       # streamlit, sqlalchemy, psycopg2-binary
‚îú‚îÄ .gitignore             # must include .streamlit/secrets.toml
‚îî‚îÄ (other files as needed)
1)

Push to GitHub (from your Codespace terminal)

Stage ‚Üí Commit ‚Üí Push ‚Üí Verify

# From the repo root in Codespaces
git status

# Stage new files + deletions
git add -A

# Commit
git commit -m "Streamlit app: add app.py + requirements; remove old main.py"

# Push
git push origin main

# Verify
git status
git log --oneline -n 1

After pushing, confirm your repo shows app.py, requirements.txt, and .gitignore on GitHub. Your local .streamlit/secrets.toml should NOT be in Git.

E)

Deploy on Streamlit Community Cloud

Create app ‚Üí Add secrets ‚Üí Restart ‚Üí Verify

  1. Create app
    • Go to Streamlit Community Cloud ‚Üí Create app
    • Select repo: AIforimpact22/learningexamples (example)
    • Branch: main
    • Main file path: app.py
    • Click Deploy
  2. Add Secrets (required)
    • App page ‚Üí ‚ãØ ‚Üí Edit secrets ‚Üí paste:
    [connections.neon]
url = "postgresql+psycopg2://USER:PASSWORD@ep-xxxx-pooler.REGION.neon.tech/DB?sslmode=require"
    • Save and Restart the app.
  3. Verify
    • Open the deployed URL.
    • The app should connect to Neon and show your pages.

If something fails

  • Check View logs from the app menu.
  • Confirm the connection string is correct, includes sslmode=require, and uses the pooled host (contains -pooler).
  • Ensure your database objects are created (e.g., schema/table exist in Neon).
¬© Hawkar ‚Äî Last updated

lessons.title: Streamlit Access Gate ‚Ä¢ Password for Security

content.body_md:
Security ‚Ä¢ Minimal

Simple Access Gate for Streamlit (No External Auth)

Password or private token via st.secrets ‚Äî quick protection for your app

Add a lightweight gate so only users with a shared password or a private tokenized link can open your app. No OAuth/SSO or external providers ‚Äî just Streamlit and .streamlit/secrets.toml.

Step 1

Add minimal auth secrets (don‚Äôt commit these)

Put secrets locally, then paste the same into Streamlit Cloud ‚Üí Edit secrets

In your local .streamlit/secrets.toml (and later in Streamlit Cloud‚Äôs Secrets), add one of these:

Option A ‚Äî Single password (easiest)

[auth]
password = "Set-A-Strong-Password-Here"

Option B ‚Äî Hashed password (no plaintext)

[auth]
password_sha256 = "PUT_SHA256_HEX_OF_YOUR_PASSWORD_HERE"

Generate the SHA-256 hash locally:

python - <<'PY'
import hashlib
print(hashlib.sha256(b"Set-A-Strong-Password-Here").hexdigest())
PY

Optional ‚Äî Private link tokens (for ‚Äúmagic links‚Äù)

[auth]
tokens = ["my-very-secret-link-token-1", "another-token"]

Anyone who opens your app with ?token=my-very-secret-link-token-1 is auto-signed-in.

Keep secrets out of Git:

echo ".streamlit/secrets.toml" >> .gitignore
Step 2

Drop-in secure version of your app.py

Tiny login gate: query-token or password ‚Üí session ‚Üí show app

Paste this over your current file (it keeps your attendance logic intact). The gate runs first; if the user is not authenticated, they‚Äôll see a sidebar login. On success, we store a flag in st.session_state. 

import streamlit as st
from sqlalchemy import text
import hashlib, hmac

st.set_page_config(page_title="Neon + Streamlit ‚Ä¢ Attendance", page_icon="üóÑÔ∏è", layout="centered")

# ---------- Simple Access Gate (password or token) ----------
def _sha256(s: str) -> str:
    return hashlib.sha256(s.encode("utf-8")).hexdigest()

def _get_query_param(name: str):
    # Works on both new & older Streamlit versions
    try:
        # Newer: st.query_params (Mapping)
        qp = st.query_params  # may raise on older versions
        val = qp.get(name, None)
        if isinstance(val, list):  # just in case
            return val[0] if val else None
        return val
    except Exception:
        # Older: experimental_get_query_params()
        val = st.experimental_get_query_params().get(name, [None])
        return val[0] if isinstance(val, list) else val

def require_login() -> bool:
    if st.session_state.get("_authed"):
        with st.sidebar:
            st.success("Signed in")
            if st.button("Sign out"):
                st.session_state.clear()
                st.rerun()
        return True

    secrets_auth = st.secrets.get("auth", {})
    # 1) Token via URL (?token=...)
    token = _get_query_param("token")
    allowed_tokens = set()
    if "tokens" in secrets_auth:
        allowed_tokens = {str(x) for x in secrets_auth["tokens"]}
    elif "token" in secrets_auth:
        allowed_tokens = {str(secrets_auth["token"])}

    if token and token in allowed_tokens:
        st.session_state["_authed"] = True
        st.session_state["_method"] = "token"
        st.rerun()

    # 2) Password in sidebar
    with st.sidebar:
        st.markdown("### Sign in")
        pw_input = st.text_input("Access password", type="password")
        if st.button("Sign in", use_container_width=True):
            ok = False
            if "password_sha256" in secrets_auth:
                ok = hmac.compare_digest(_sha256(pw_input), secrets_auth["password_sha256"])
            elif "password" in secrets_auth:
                ok = hmac.compare_digest(pw_input, secrets_auth["password"])
            if ok:
                st.session_state["_authed"] = True
                st.session_state["_method"] = "password"
                st.toast("Signed in")
                st.rerun()
            else:
                st.error("Invalid password")
    st.info("Enter the access password to continue.")
    return False

# Gate everything below
if not require_login():
    st.stop()

# ---------- App content (unchanged except moved below the gate) ----------
st.title("Employees + Attendance")
st.caption("Neon (Postgres) backend ‚Ä¢ Streamlit frontend")

# 1) Connect via secrets (you already set [connections.neon].url in secrets.toml)
conn = st.connection("neon", type="sql")

# 2) Bootstrap ONLY the new table (safe to run; does not touch app.employees)
with conn.session as s:
    s.execute(text("""
        CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS app.attendance_log (
            log_id BIGSERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
            employee_id TEXT NOT NULL REFERENCES app.employees(employee_id)
                ON UPDATE CASCADE ON DELETE RESTRICT,
            date DATE NOT NULL,
            check_in_time TIMESTAMPTZ,
            check_out_time TIMESTAMPTZ,
            status TEXT,
            notes TEXT,
            CONSTRAINT attendance_unique_per_day UNIQUE (employee_id, date)
        )
    """))
    s.execute(text("""
        CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_attendance_employee_date
        ON app.attendance_log (employee_id, date)
    """))
    s.commit()

# 3) Employees list (for UI selection) ‚Äî reads existing table, no DDL
employees_df = conn.query("""
    SELECT employee_id, first_name, last_name
    FROM app.employees
    ORDER BY first_name, last_name
""", ttl="2m")

st.subheader("Attendance (Today)")
if employees_df.empty:
    st.info("No employees found. Add employees first, then return to this page.")
else:
    options = employees_df.apply(
        lambda r: f"{r['first_name']} {r['last_name']} ({r['employee_id']})", axis=1
    ).tolist()
    choice = st.selectbox("Select employee", options)
    eid = employees_df.iloc[options.index(choice)]["employee_id"]

    c1, c2, c3 = st.columns(3)

    with c1:
        if st.button("Check In"):
            try:
                with conn.session as s:
                    s.execute(text("""
                        INSERT INTO app.attendance_log (employee_id, date, check_in_time, status)
                        VALUES (:eid, CURRENT_DATE, now(), 'Present')
                        ON CONFLICT (employee_id, date)
                        DO UPDATE SET check_in_time = COALESCE(app.attendance_log.check_in_time, EXCLUDED.check_in_time)
                    """), {"eid": eid})
                    s.commit()
                st.success(f"{eid} checked in.")
            except Exception as e:
                st.error(f"Check-in failed: {e}")

    with c2:
        if st.button("Check Out"):
            try:
                with conn.session as s:
                    res = s.execute(text("""
                        UPDATE app.attendance_log
                           SET check_out_time = now()
                         WHERE employee_id = :eid
                           AND date = CURRENT_DATE
                           AND check_out_time IS NULL
                    """), {"eid": eid})
                    s.commit()
                st.success(f"{eid} checked out.") if res.rowcount else st.warning("No open check-in for today.")
            except Exception as e:
                st.error(f"Check-out failed: {e}")

    with c3:
        status_note = st.text_input("Optional status/notes (e.g., Sick, Leave)")
        if st.button("Set Status/Note"):
            try:
                with conn.session as s:
                    s.execute(text("""
                        INSERT INTO app.attendance_log (employee_id, date)
                        VALUES (:eid, CURRENT_DATE)
                        ON CONFLICT (employee_id, date) DO NOTHING
                    """), {"eid": eid})
                    s.execute(text("""
                        UPDATE app.attendance_log
                           SET status = :st, notes = :nt
                         WHERE employee_id = :eid AND date = CURRENT_DATE
                    """), {"st": status_note or None, "nt": status_note or None, "eid": eid})
                    s.commit()
                st.success("Status/notes updated.")
            except Exception as e:
                st.error(f"Update failed: {e}")

# 4) Views
st.subheader("Today‚Äôs attendance")
today_df = conn.query("""
    SELECT
      al.date,
      e.employee_id,
      e.first_name,
      e.last_name,
      al.check_in_time,
      al.check_out_time,
      al.status,
      al.notes
    FROM app.attendance_log al
    JOIN app.employees e ON e.employee_id = al.employee_id
    WHERE al.date = CURRENT_DATE
    ORDER BY e.first_name, e.last_name
""", ttl="30s")
st.dataframe(today_df, use_container_width=True)

st.subheader("Recent attendance (last 30 days)")
recent_df = conn.query("""
    SELECT
      al.date,
      e.employee_id,
      e.first_name,
      e.last_name,
      al.check_in_time,
      al.check_out_time,
      al.status
    FROM app.attendance_log al
    JOIN app.employees e ON e.employee_id = al.employee_id
    WHERE al.date >= CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '30 days'
    ORDER BY al.date DESC, e.first_name, e.last_name
""", ttl="2m")
st.dataframe(recent_df, use_container_width=True)

# 5) Health check
st.caption("DB server time:")
st.write(conn.query("SELECT now() AS server_time;").iloc[0]["server_time"])
Step 3

How to use it

Password sign-in, magic links, and sign out

  • Password sign-in: open your app, enter the password in the sidebar, click Sign in.
  • Magic link sign-in: share https://your-app.streamlit.app/?token=THE_TOKEN with trusted users (when tokens=[...] is set in secrets).
  • Sign out: use the sidebar button.

This approach is simple (no OAuth/SSO), private (secrets live in Streamlit Cloud‚Äôs Secrets), stateless (per-session), and flexible (password or token links). You can later upgrade to SSO as needed.

def _sha256(s: str) -> str:
    return hashlib.sha256(s.encode("utf-8")).hexdigest()

def _get_query_param(name: str):
    try:
        qp = st.query_params
        val = qp.get(name, None)
        if isinstance(val, list):
            return val[0] if val else None
        return val
    except Exception:
        val = st.experimental_get_query_params().get(name, [None])
        return val[0] if isinstance(val, list) else val

def require_login() -> bool:
    if st.session_state.get("_authed"):
        with st.sidebar:
            st.success(f"Signed in ({st.session_state.get('_method','')})")
            if st.button("Sign out", use_container_width=True):
                st.session_state.clear()
                st.rerun()
        return True

    secrets_auth = st.secrets.get("auth", {})
    # URL token (magic link): ?token=XXXX
    token = _get_query_param("token")
    allowed_tokens = set()
    if "tokens" in secrets_auth:
        allowed_tokens = {str(x) for x in secrets_auth["tokens"]}
    elif "token" in secrets_auth:
        allowed_tokens = {str(secrets_auth["token"])}

    if token and token in allowed_tokens:
        st.session_state["_authed"] = True
        st.session_state["_method"] = "token"
        st.rerun()

    with st.sidebar:
        st.markdown("### Sign in")
        pw_input = st.text_input("Access password", type="password")
        if st.button("Sign in", use_container_width=True):
            ok = False
            if "password_sha256" in secrets_auth:
                ok = hmac.compare_digest(_sha256(pw_input), secrets_auth["password_sha256"])
            elif "password" in secrets_auth:
                ok = hmac.compare_digest(pw_input, secrets_auth["password"])
            if ok:
                st.session_state["_authed"] = True
                st.session_state["_method"] = "password"
                st.toast("Signed in")
                st.rerun()
            else:
                st.error("Invalid password")
    st.info("Enter the access password to continue.")
    return False

if not require_login():
    st.stop()

def list_employees(search: str | None):
    q = """
        SELECT employee_id, first_name, last_name, email, department, job_title,
               status, hire_date, created_at
        FROM app.employees
        {where}
        ORDER BY created_at DESC
        LIMIT 500
    """
    if search:
        like = f"%{search.strip()}%"
        return conn.query(
            q.format(where="WHERE employee_id ILIKE :q OR first_name ILIKE :q OR last_name ILIKE :q OR email ILIKE :q"),
            params={"q": like}, ttl="10s"
        )
    else:
        return conn.query(q.format(where=""), ttl="10s")

def get_employee(eid: str):
    df = conn.query("""
        SELECT employee_id, first_name, last_name, email, department, job_title,
               status, hire_date
        FROM app.employees
        WHERE employee_id = :eid
        LIMIT 1
    """, params={"eid": eid}, ttl=0)
    return None if df.empty else df.iloc[0].to_dict()

def insert_employee(payload: dict):
    with conn.session as s:
        s.execute(text("""
            INSERT INTO app.employees (employee_id, first_name, last_name, email,
                                       department, job_title, status, hire_date)
            VALUES (:employee_id, :first_name, :last_name, :email,
                    :department, :job_title, :status, :hire_date)
        """), payload)
        s.commit()

def update_employee(eid: str, payload: dict):
    with conn.session as s:
        s.execute(text("""
            UPDATE app.employees
               SET first_name = :first_name,
                   last_name  = :last_name,
                   email      = :email,
                   department = :department,
                   job_title  = :job_title,
                   status     = :status,
                   hire_date  = :hire_date
             WHERE employee_id = :employee_id
        """), {**payload, "employee_id": eid})
        s.commit()

def delete_employee(eid: str):
    with conn.session as s:
        s.execute(text("DELETE FROM app.employees WHERE employee_id = :eid"), {"eid": eid})
        s.commit()

def _to_date(val):
    if isinstance(val, date):
        return val
    if isinstance(val, datetime):
        return val.date()
    if isinstance(val, str):
        try:
            return date.fromisoformat(val)
        except Exception:
            return date.today()
    return date.today()

How to use the CRUD

One place to manage employees safely

  • Open Employees (CRUD) from the sidebar.
  • Create: expand "‚ûï Create new employee", fill the form, click Create employee.
  • Read: use the search box (ID, name, email). Results appear in a table.
  • Update: pick a row under "Edit / Delete", modify fields, click Update.
  • Delete: choose the employee ‚Üí Delete ‚Üí confirm checkbox ‚Üí delete.
    Note: If the employee has attendance rows, the DB will reject the delete (ON DELETE RESTRICT) ‚Äî this protects your data.

Safe SQL ‚Ä¢ No schema duplication ‚Ä¢ Easy to extend
